Which is more important-- personal privacy or controlling drug use of employees? * The right to privacy The Constitution does not specifically mention a right to privacy. However, Supreme Court decisions over the years have established that the right to privacy is a basic human right, and as such is protected by virtue of the 9th Amendment. The right to privacy has come to the public's attention via several controversial Supreme Court rulings, including several dealing with contraception (the Griswold and Eisenstadt cases), interracial marriage (the Loving case), and abortion (the well-known Roe v. Wade case). In addition, it is said that a right to privacy is inherent in many of the amendments in the Bill of Rights, such as the 3rd, the 4th's search and seizure limits, and the 5th's self- incrimination limit. from urlLink http://www.usconstitution.net/constnot.html#elec

But what should people do if they don't have the perfect employer? Take for instance, elementary school teachers. They have to take care of 25-30 seven year olds from 8am-4pm, five days a week. Most school teachers don't have any other adult in the room. If they have to use the bathroom, they must wait until their 30 minute lunch break or until the kids leave at 4pm. Most don't have a phone in their room. Some have computers, but schools have firewalled most sites to protect the children. So you usually can't access private email. Most teachers work from about 7 in the morning until 6pm at night, grading, scheduling, and organizing. The average teacher makes in the low to mid $30s, which works out to be $12-14/ hour, once you've taken out taxes, insurance, and certification fees.
What is your employer's responsability to you? A few things to think about: Different forms of compensation; morale; safety; information.

So many times we take the national or local news to be the truth. We don't see the news on the same level as other television programs or talk shows. But what we tend to forget is that news programs are in the entertainment buisness. Many conservatives accuse most national news media as being liberally biased. At the same time, liberals complain about the majority of talk radio shows being mostly conservative. Do you think that national and local news shows ever bend the truth or omit parts of a story in order to favor a particular political party or also to increase the entertainment value of the story? Do you think this is right? Should news outlets be required to stick strictly to the facts, or should they be allowed to present the stories the way they choose because they are just anonther television program trying to get ratings?
